Comment: The Nimzo-Indian, a defence I've rarely played. But I should; it's direct - Black gets his pieces out quickly to enable fast castling, and often doubles White's pawns.

White can play 4.Qc2 here to avoid the doubled pawns...
But in this line White accepts the doubled pawns for a strong pawn centre. It also means Black has no dark-squared Bishop.
But in this line White accepts the doubled pawns for a strong pawn centre. It also means Black has no dark-squared Bishop.
Black must counter quickly in the centre.

Now my opponent has gone a little astray, but not disastrously so. It's just that advancing the pawn is rather against the spirit of the variation, I would have thought. White's strength is in those pawns, and more usual is 6.e3 or even 6.f3, which I see was the most popular move in the database. Already there are only nine games with this position.
Now my move is rather against the idea of the opening - swift castling. Instead I develop a piece and in fact don't castle K-side at all.
The lack of Black's dark-squared Bishop is immediately exploited.
So the attacker must be driven away.
And again...
And again...
Black has really seized the initiative now.
Black has really seized the initiative now.
White really doesn't want a second set of doubled pawns, and this is the only way to avoid them.
A little drastic, but threatening to cut off the Bishop.
Instead it's driven back.
Instead it's driven back.
At this point we are a few moves out of the databse and I'm unsure of the best continuation. I feel like I'm on top...
And I'm sure White won't want to take this pawn and saddle himself with pawns that are doubles and isolated.
He can, however, drive away my Knight quite easily.
I'm eyeing that open diagonal against the KIng, but I can't see how to exploit it.

White can actually exploit the fact that I didn't castle when I had the opportunity, and play 14.Qg6+, preventing castling altogether. Instead he tries to challenge in the centre and free his Bishop. But this just loses a pawn.
16...Qxd4 is better, since White is probably obliged to exchange Queens, but I feel like the momentum is with me...

16...Qxd4 is better, since White is probably obliged to exchange Queens, but I feel like the momentum is with me...

White can accomplish what he wants to accomplish by castling Q-side, but probably didn't fancy all that space. In the end, his centrally placed King was his undoing. Curiously, I hadn't even spotted this, which rather forces me back...
